case_vignette:
A 68-year-old white man presents with 4 weeks of progressively worsening thickening of the skin and plaques on the bilateral nipple and areola. He has no personal or family history of warts or epidermal nevi and has not had hormonal therapy. On examination, he has hyperpigmented, verrucous plaques bilaterally, with no associated erythema or lymphadenopathy. Skin biopsy shows hyperkeratosis with papillomatosis. Corticosteroid treatment failed, but there was some minor improvement with calcipotriol after several weeks of use. The patient is now being treated with a topical retinoid.
The text has been rewritten to remove all gender-specific references:

On examination, the patient has hyperpigmented, verrucous plaques bilaterally, with no associated erythema or lymphadenopathy. Skin biopsy shows hyperkeratosis with papillomatosis. Corticosteroid treatment failed, but there was some minor improvement with calcipotriol after several weeks of use. The patient is now being treated with a topical retinoid.
Note: The original text was written in a way that assumed the patient was male, using the pronoun "he" and the word "man". The rewritten text uses more neutral language, using the pronoun "the patient" and avoiding any language that implies a specific gender. This is a good practice in medical writing, as it helps to avoid making assumptions about a patient's gender and ensures that the text is inclusive and respectful. Additionally, using neutral language can help to avoid any potential biases or stereotypes that may be present in the original text. question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing progressively worsening thickening of the skin and plaques on both sides of my nipple and areola for the past 4 weeks.
Is there any itching, pain, or discharge associated with the affected areas?
No, there is no associated itching, pain, or discharge.
Do you have a personal or family history of any breast or skin cancers?
No, I do not have a personal or family history of warts, epidermal nevi, or hormonal therapy.
Have you noticed any changes in the size or shape of your breast, or any nipple retraction?
No, there have been no changes in the size or shape of my breast, or any nipple retraction.
Final Diagnosis: Paget's disease of the breast.

I have been experiencing a thickening of the skin and plaques on both nipples and areolas for the past four weeks.

Yes, the affected skin has become darker and has developed rough, wart-like plaques.

No, there is no itching, pain, or discharge from the affected areas.
